main_definition: The name 'Edwards' is primarily a surname of English origin, but it can also refer to an idiomatic expression related to the famous American tennis player Arthur Ashe or represent various other concepts in different contexts.

meanings_and_examples.example: John Edwards is a common English surname.

Arthur Ashe was an American professional tennis player whose last name 'Ashe' became associated with the idiomatic expression 'Edwards' due to his competitive nature and success, although he wasn't directly referred to as Edwards.

When someone is described as having an 'Edwardsian spirit', it refers to a fierce determination reminiscent of the competitive nature and fighting spirit displayed by Arthur Ashe, who despite his polio diagnosis, went on to become one of the greatest tennis players in history.
